description: Understand and use key income terms: gross vs net pay, salary vs hourly, withholdings, deductions

coreConcepts: Gross pay: total earnings before anything is taken out
Net pay: what you actually take home (gross minus deductions)
Salary: fixed annual amount divided into pay periods
Hourly: paid per hour worked, varies with hours
commonMistakes: Thinking salary = take-home pay
Not realizing hourly workers can earn more than salaried workers depending on hours
Confusing deductions with expenses
teachingTips: Use a real-looking pay stub as the anchor document
Have students calculate the gap between gross and net — the shock factor teaches
Compare: $40,000 salary vs $20/hr — which pays more? (depends on hours)

description: Read and interpret a pay stub: identify gross pay, taxes, withholdings, deductions, and net pay

coreConcepts: Federal income tax, state income tax, FICA (Social Security + Medicare)
Pre-tax deductions: health insurance, 401(k) contributions
Post-tax deductions: Roth contributions, garnishments
Year-to-date (YTD) totals and what they tell you
commonMistakes: Not realizing how much taxes take — students are genuinely shocked
Confusing federal and state taxes
Not understanding that health insurance premiums come out of the paycheck
teachingTips: Walk through a sample pay stub line by line — no skipping
Have students calculate: what percentage of gross pay was taken?
Ask: if you got paid $1,000 gross, how much actually hits your bank?

description: Understand checking vs savings accounts, debit vs credit cards, and basic banking operations

coreConcepts: Checking account: for daily spending, debit card linked, earns little/no interest
Savings account: for storing money, earns interest, limited withdrawals
Debit card: spends YOUR money directly from checking
Credit card: spends BORROWED money that you must pay back with interest
commonMistakes: Thinking debit and credit cards are the same thing
Not understanding overdraft fees
Believing a credit card is 'free money'
teachingTips: Use the 'whose money is it?' test: debit = yours, credit = bank's
Show what a $35 overdraft fee looks like on a $5 purchase
Introduce the concept: credit cards are a tool, not a trap — IF used correctly

description: Distinguish wants from needs using actual budget numbers, not abstract categories

coreConcepts: Needs: housing, food, utilities, transportation, insurance — must-haves
Wants: entertainment, dining out, subscriptions, upgrades — nice-to-haves
The gray area: internet (need for school/work?), car vs bus, phone plan tier
Quantify wants: add up monthly subscriptions and 'small' purchases
commonMistakes: Labeling everything as a need
Not tracking small recurring costs (they add up fast)
Thinking wants are bad — they're fine IF the math works
teachingTips: Have students list their own monthly subscriptions and total them up
Use real numbers: $15/month × 12 = $180/year. Worth it?
Frame as trade-offs, not moral judgments: 'What would you give up for...?'

description: Organize expenses into fixed vs variable categories and identify all budget line items

coreConcepts: Fixed expenses: same amount every month (rent, car payment, insurance)
Variable expenses: change month to month (groceries, gas, utilities)
Common categories: housing, transportation, food, utilities, insurance, personal, savings
The 50/30/20 guideline: 50% needs, 30% wants, 20% savings/debt
commonMistakes: Forgetting categories entirely (insurance, subscriptions, personal care)
Underestimating variable expenses
Not treating savings as a budget line item
teachingTips: Start with a complete list before assigning dollar amounts
Use real average costs for your region when possible
Savings is not 'leftover' — it's a planned expense

description: Build and interpret monthly cash-flow tables: total income minus total expenses equals surplus or deficit

coreConcepts: Cash flow = income - expenses
Positive cash flow (surplus): money left over after all expenses
Negative cash flow (deficit): spending more than earning
Organizing in a table: category | budgeted | actual | difference
commonMistakes: Forgetting to use NET income (not gross) as the starting point
Not tracking actual spending vs budgeted amounts
Treating a one-month surplus as permanent
teachingTips: Build a cash-flow table step by step — income at top, expenses below, bottom line at bottom
Use red/green coloring: surplus = green, deficit = red
Have students adjust the budget when it doesn't balance — that's the real skill

description: Plan for non-monthly expenses using sinking funds: car repairs, gifts, annual subscriptions

coreConcepts: Irregular expenses: don't happen every month but WILL happen (car maintenance, holiday gifts, school supplies)
Sinking fund: set aside money each month for a future known expense
Calculation: annual cost ÷ 12 = monthly sinking fund amount
Examples: $600 car maintenance ÷ 12 = $50/month sinking fund
commonMistakes: Pretending irregular expenses won't happen
Treating every unexpected expense as an emergency (many are predictable)
Not adjusting the monthly budget to include sinking fund contributions
teachingTips: List common irregular expenses and have students estimate annual costs
Show: a $600 car repair is either a crisis or a $50/month plan
Connect to the emergency fund distinction: irregular ≠ emergency

description: Make budget decisions by comparing trade-offs: what to cut, what to keep, and why

coreConcepts: Trade-off: giving up one thing to get another
Budget adjustments: if income drops or expenses rise, something must change
Prioritization: needs first, then savings, then wants
Scenario analysis: 'what if rent goes up $200?' or 'what if you lose overtime?'
commonMistakes: Only cutting wants without looking at needs (sometimes you can reduce needs too — cheaper phone plan, roommate)
Making cuts that aren't sustainable long-term
Not considering the ripple effect of changes
teachingTips: Give students a budget that doesn't balance and have them fix it
Present 'what would you cut?' scenarios and require written justification
Compare two students' solutions — there's no single right answer, but the math must work

displayName: Percent of a Number & Percent Change
description: Calculate percent of a number and percent increase/decrease in financial contexts

coreConcepts: Percent of a number: multiply by the decimal form (25% of $80 = 0.25 × $80 = $20)
Percent increase: new = original × (1 + rate)
Percent decrease: new = original × (1 - rate)
Percent change formula: (new - original) / original × 100
commonMistakes: Calculating 20% of $50 as $50 - 20 = $30 instead of $50 × 0.20 = $10
Forgetting the base changes with successive percent changes
Dividing by the new value instead of the original when finding percent change
teachingTips: Multiplier method is fastest: 30% off = multiply by 0.70
Use money contexts exclusively — percent fluency IS financial literacy
The '10% up then 10% down' problem opens eyes

description: Calculate savings from discounts and coupons, including stacked and sequential discounts

coreConcepts: Single discount: sale price = original × (1 - discount rate)
Sequential discounts: apply one at a time (30% off then extra 10% off ≠ 40% off)
Coupon: fixed dollar amount off vs percentage off — which saves more depends on price
Always compare final prices, not just discount percentages
commonMistakes: Adding sequential discounts (20% + 10% ≠ 30%)
Assuming a higher percentage discount is always the better deal
Forgetting that the coupon might apply before or after the sale price
teachingTips: Show side-by-side: 30% off then 10% off vs. straight 40% off
Use real retail scenarios: '$5 off coupon' vs '15% off' on a $40 item
The key question: 'what do I actually pay?'

description: Calculate sales tax, restaurant tips, and retail markup/markdown on purchases

coreConcepts: Sales tax: total = price × (1 + tax rate). Tax rates vary by state/city.
Tip: total = subtotal × (1 + tip rate). Standard: 15-20% of pre-tax subtotal.
Markup: selling price = cost × (1 + markup rate). How stores make profit.
Markdown: sale price = original × (1 - markdown rate).
commonMistakes: Calculating tip on the total after tax instead of the pre-tax subtotal
Forgetting that tax is added ON TOP of the price (not included)
Not realizing markup can be 100%+ (a $5 item selling for $12)
teachingTips: Teach the '10% trick' for quick mental tip estimates: find 10%, then adjust
Use real local tax rates for practice problems
Restaurant check math is the most immediately useful skill here

description: Calculate unit prices and use them to identify the best value among different sizes and brands

coreConcepts: Unit price = total price ÷ quantity (price per ounce, per item, per serving)
Lower unit price = better value (usually)
Bigger isn't always cheaper — always calculate, don't assume
Consider waste: the 5 lb bag is cheaper per pound, but will you use it all?
commonMistakes: Dividing quantity by price instead of price by quantity
Assuming the bigger package is always the better deal
Not comparing the same units (price per ounce vs price per pound)
teachingTips: Use real grocery store examples with actual prices
Have students find unit prices on items they actually buy
Add the waste factor: 'Is the bulk buy worth it if half goes bad?'

description: Calculate simple interest using I = Prt and find total amount in savings or loan contexts

coreConcepts: Simple interest formula: I = Prt (Principal × rate × time)
Total amount: A = P + I = P(1 + rt)
P = starting amount, r = annual rate as decimal, t = time in years
Works for both savings (you earn) and loans (you owe)
commonMistakes: Forgetting to convert percent to decimal (5% = 0.05, not 5)
Using months instead of years without converting (6 months = 0.5 years)
Confusing interest earned with total balance
teachingTips: Start with savings: 'you deposit $500 at 3% for 2 years' — friendly context
Then flip to loans: 'same formula, but now interest works AGAINST you'
Compare: $1,000 at 2% simple interest for 5 years — how much interest?

description: Understand compound interest conceptually, calculate with A = P(1 + r/n)^(nt), and compare to simple interest

coreConcepts: Compound interest: earning interest ON your interest
Formula: A = P(1 + r/n)^(nt) where n = compounding frequency
More frequent compounding = slightly more growth
APY (Annual Percentage Yield): the effective annual rate after compounding
commonMistakes: Not understanding why compound > simple (it's interest on interest)
Confusing APR (stated rate) with APY (effective rate after compounding)
Using the formula wrong: forgetting to divide r by n AND multiply t by n
teachingTips: Start conceptual: '$100 at 10% — after year 1 you have $110, year 2 you earn 10% of $110 not $100'
Use a table to show year-by-year growth before introducing the formula
Compare simple vs compound side-by-side over 10, 20, 30 years — the gap is the lesson

description: Calculate target emergency fund size (3-6 months of expenses) and plan how long it takes to build

coreConcepts: Emergency fund: savings set aside for unexpected events (job loss, medical, major repair)
Target: 3-6 months of essential expenses
Calculate: monthly essentials × target months = goal amount
Time to build: goal ÷ monthly savings contribution = months needed
commonMistakes: Using total income instead of essential expenses for the target
Not including irregular essentials in the monthly calculation
Getting discouraged by how long it takes — start with a $500 mini-goal
teachingTips: Use a specific profile: '$2,400/month essentials × 3 months = $7,200 target'
Show timeline: saving $200/month → 36 months to hit 3 months of expenses
Distinguish: sinking fund (for known future costs) vs emergency fund (for unknowns)

description: Understand opportunity cost as the value of the next-best alternative you give up when making a financial choice

coreConcepts: Opportunity cost: what you give up when you choose option A over option B
Every dollar spent is a dollar that can't be saved or spent elsewhere
Opportunity cost of holding cash: inflation eats purchasing power over time
Time has opportunity cost too: working overtime vs free time
commonMistakes: Thinking opportunity cost only applies to money (it also applies to time)
Not quantifying the alternative — 'what would that $200 be worth invested?'
Ignoring opportunity cost when it's uncomfortable
teachingTips: Start simple: 'You have $50 — concert ticket or save it. What's the opportunity cost of each?'
Show the invested alternative: '$50/month in an index fund for 40 years = ?'
Keep it practical, not preachy — the goal is awareness, not guilt

description: Understand what a credit score is, what factors affect it, and why it matters for loans and rates

coreConcepts: Credit score range: 300-850. Higher = better.
Five factors: payment history (35%), amounts owed (30%), length of history (15%), new credit (10%), credit mix (10%)
Good credit = lower interest rates on loans, better rental applications, sometimes cheaper insurance
Building credit: use a card, pay it off IN FULL every month
commonMistakes: Thinking you need to carry a balance to build credit (you don't)
Not realizing late payments stay on your record for 7 years
Opening many credit cards to 'build credit faster' (hurts in the short term)
teachingTips: Use the 'report card for borrowing' analogy
Show the rate difference: 4% vs 8% on a $20,000 car loan — how much more do you pay?
Emphasize: credit score is a TOOL, not a moral judgment

description: Calculate credit card interest, understand minimum payments, and see the true cost of carrying a balance

coreConcepts: APR: annual percentage rate (typically 18-25% for credit cards)
Monthly interest: APR ÷ 12 applied to your balance
Minimum payment trap: paying minimum = mostly interest, barely touching principal
Example: $3,000 balance at 22% APR, minimum payment = 15+ years to pay off
commonMistakes: Thinking the minimum payment is a reasonable way to pay off debt
Not realizing how quickly interest compounds on credit card balances
Ignoring the APR when signing up for a card (they all look the same until you carry a balance)
teachingTips: The minimum payment horror story is the most powerful lesson in this course
Show a payoff table: $3,000 at 22% with $60 minimum → total paid is ~$7,000+
Compare: pay $60/month (minimum) vs $200/month — time and total cost difference

description: Understand loan terms (principal, interest rate, term), calculate total cost, and compare loan options

coreConcepts: Principal: the amount you borrow
Interest rate: the cost of borrowing (annual percentage)
Term: how long you have to pay it back (months or years)
Total cost of loan = monthly payment × number of payments. Compare this to principal.
Monthly payment: depends on principal, rate, and term
commonMistakes: Only comparing monthly payments without looking at total cost
Thinking a longer term is always better (lower monthly payment but way more total interest)
Not understanding that a lower rate saves far more than a lower monthly payment
teachingTips: Car loan comparison: same car, 3-year vs 6-year loan — show total cost difference
Use given monthly payment tables rather than deriving the formula
The question is always: 'what does this loan REALLY cost?'

description: Understand how loan payments split between principal and interest over time (early = mostly interest)

coreConcepts: Early payments: mostly interest, little principal
Late payments: mostly principal, little interest
Why: interest is calculated on remaining balance — larger balance = more interest
Extra payments early on save the most money over the life of the loan
commonMistakes: Thinking each payment reduces the balance by the full payment amount
Not understanding why extra payments early in a loan save so much
Confusing total payments with principal reduction
teachingTips: Show a 3-4 row amortization snippet: payment #1 vs payment #60 on a car loan
Visual: bar chart showing interest vs principal portions over time
The 'aha' moment: 'I paid $500 but only $150 went to my balance?!'

description: Identify red flags of predatory loans: payday loans, excessive fees, balloon payments, and high-pressure tactics

coreConcepts: Payday loans: short-term, extremely high APR (often 400%+)
Red flags: 'guaranteed approval', no credit check, pressure to sign immediately
Balloon payments: low payments then a huge final payment
Predatory tactics: targeting people with low credit, hiding fees in fine print
commonMistakes: Thinking payday loans are a reasonable option for emergencies
Not reading the fine print / terms and conditions
Assuming all lenders are regulated and fair
teachingTips: Calculate the real cost: borrow $500 from a payday lender at 400% APR for 2 weeks
Compare: payday loan vs credit card vs personal loan — same amount, wildly different costs
Frame as 'how to protect yourself' not 'never borrow money'

description: Calculate gross pay for hourly, salaried, and commission-based jobs and compare across structures

coreConcepts: Hourly pay: gross = hourly rate × hours worked
Salary: gross = annual salary ÷ number of pay periods (26 biweekly, 24 semimonthly, 12 monthly)
Commission: base pay + (sales × commission rate)
Comparing: salary stability vs hourly flexibility vs commission earning potential
commonMistakes: Comparing annual salary to hourly rate without converting to the same basis
Forgetting that salaried workers don't earn overtime (usually)
Not considering that commission income varies month to month
teachingTips: Convert everything to the same basis for comparison: annual or hourly
$50,000/year ÷ 2,080 hours = ~$24.04/hour — is that more or less than $22/hour with overtime?
Present real job offer scenarios and have students decide

description: Calculate gross pay with overtime (time-and-a-half) and read/build timesheets

coreConcepts: Overtime: hours over 40/week paid at 1.5× regular rate (time-and-a-half)
Gross pay with OT: (40 × rate) + (OT hours × rate × 1.5)
Timesheet: records hours worked per day/week
Some jobs: double-time on holidays, different OT rules
commonMistakes: Applying overtime rate to ALL hours instead of just the hours over 40
Forgetting that 1.5× means the rate, not $1.50 extra
Not reading the timesheet correctly (rounding errors, break deductions)
teachingTips: Use a weekly timesheet and have students total the hours first, then calculate pay
Show the pay difference: 45 hours vs 40 hours — overtime really adds up
Connect to real scenarios: 'Is working Saturday worth it?'

description: Understand W-2 vs 1099, progressive taxation concept, and estimate take-home pay after taxes

coreConcepts: W-2 employee: employer withholds taxes, provides benefits, pays employer share of FICA
1099 contractor: no withholding, pays own taxes quarterly, pays BOTH sides of FICA (~15.3%)
Progressive tax: higher income → higher tax rate ON THE AMOUNT ABOVE each bracket
Effective tax rate: total tax ÷ total income (always less than your top bracket)
commonMistakes: Thinking all income is taxed at your highest bracket (the #1 tax misconception)
Not realizing 1099 workers pay roughly double the FICA tax of W-2 workers
Confusing marginal rate with effective rate
teachingTips: Use a visual: 'Fill the buckets' model for progressive tax brackets
Simple estimate: assume 22-25% total taxes (federal + state + FICA) for a W-2 worker
Compare: $60,000 W-2 job vs $60,000 1099 contract — what's the take-home difference?

description: Understand and value employer benefits: health insurance premiums, 401(k) match, PTO, and total compensation

coreConcepts: Total compensation = salary + employer-paid benefits
Health insurance: employer covers part of premium, employee pays the rest (pre-tax)
401(k) match: employer matches a percentage of your contribution — free money
PTO (paid time off): vacation + sick days = paid days you don't work
commonMistakes: Only comparing base salary without considering benefits
Not taking a 401(k) match = leaving free money on the table
Undervaluing health insurance (a $6,000/year employer contribution is real money)
teachingTips: Job offer comparison: $55K with great benefits vs $62K with nothing — which is really more?
Quantify benefits in dollars: 'Your employer pays $500/month for your health insurance = $6,000/year'
The 401(k) match calculation: '4% match on $50K = $2,000/year free'

description: Understand why investing matters: inflation erodes purchasing power, and growth beats savings account rates

coreConcepts: Inflation: prices rise ~2-4% per year — your money buys less over time
Savings account rate (~0.5-5% APY) may not beat inflation in some periods
Investing: putting money into assets that grow faster than inflation (historically ~7-10%/year for stocks)
Risk vs reward: higher potential returns = higher risk of loss
commonMistakes: Thinking keeping cash in a savings account is 'safe' (inflation risk)
Expecting guaranteed returns from investing (it fluctuates)
Confusing investing with gambling
teachingTips: Show inflation impact: $100 today buys the same as ~$67 from 10 years ago
Savings account vs stock market over 30 years — the gap is enormous
Investing is NOT day-trading or meme stocks — frame it as long-term wealth building

displayName: Investment Types: Stocks, Bonds, Index Funds
description: Understand basic investment types and the concept of diversification

coreConcepts: Stock: owning a small piece of a company. Higher risk, higher potential return.
Bond: lending money to a company or government. Lower risk, lower return.
Index fund: a bundle of many stocks that tracks the whole market. Diversified by default.
Diversification: don't put all your eggs in one basket — spread across investments
commonMistakes: Thinking you need to pick individual stocks to invest
Not understanding that index funds give you instant diversification
Expecting investing to make you rich quickly (it's a decades-long game)
teachingTips: Pizza analogy: stock = one slice, index fund = the whole pizza (many companies)
Historical S&P 500 average: ~10%/year over long periods (but varies year to year)
Keep it conceptual — students don't need to know how to buy stocks yet

description: Understand the basics of 401(k) and Roth IRA accounts and why starting early matters

coreConcepts: 401(k): employer-sponsored, contributions reduce taxable income NOW, taxed when withdrawn in retirement
Roth IRA: contributions made with after-tax money, grows tax-FREE, withdrawals tax-free in retirement
Employer match: if employer matches 4%, contribute at least 4% — it's 100% return on that money
Contribution limits exist (but students won't hit them for years)
commonMistakes: Not contributing enough to get the full employer match
Thinking retirement planning can wait until you're 40
Withdrawing from retirement accounts early (penalties + taxes)
teachingTips: Keep it high-level: 'pre-tax bucket' (401k) vs 'after-tax bucket' (Roth)
The match calculation: '4% of $50K = $2,000. Employer GIVES you $2,000. For free.'
Show the 'start at 22 vs start at 32' graph — that's the entire lesson

description: Calculate and visualize long-term compound growth to prove why starting early beats starting big

coreConcepts: Rule of 72: years to double ≈ 72 ÷ annual return rate (at 8%, doubles every ~9 years)
Starting at 22 vs 32: 10 extra years of compounding makes a MASSIVE difference
Regular contributions: $200/month at 8% for 40 years → ~$700,000+
Time is the most powerful variable — more powerful than the amount you invest
commonMistakes: Thinking you need a lot of money to start investing (you don't — $50/month works)
Underestimating the power of time (the growth curve is exponential, not linear)
Panicking during market drops and selling (long-term strategy beats short-term reactions)
teachingTips: The side-by-side comparison: Person A invests $200/month from age 22-32 then stops vs Person B invests $200/month from age 32-62. A wins.
Use a compound growth calculator and let students experiment
This is the 'start early' proof — make it visual, make it concrete

description: Identify common financial scam red flags: guaranteed returns, urgency tactics, unsolicited offers, and too-good-to-be-true promises

coreConcepts: Red flag #1: 'Guaranteed' high returns (no legitimate investment guarantees returns)
Red flag #2: Urgency and pressure ('Act NOW or miss out!')
Red flag #3: Unsolicited offers (someone you didn't ask is offering you money)
Red flag #4: 'Get rich quick' / MLM / crypto promises with no clear explanation of how
commonMistakes: Thinking scams only target old people (they target everyone, especially online)
Trusting something because it looks professional or a friend shared it
Not verifying credentials: is this person/company actually registered?
teachingTips: Show real scam examples (anonymized) — students learn from patterns
The 'if it sounds too good to be true' test is genuinely useful
Teach the pause: 'Never make a financial decision under pressure. Sleep on it.'
